title.narrative: COMMUNITY HEALTH

description.narrative: Increased capacity to deliver high impact community based health interventions for women, newborns and under 5 children, including promotion of healthy behaviors, with special focus on gender equality and the most vulnerable, in all 13 districts by 2018, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Child Health, Early Childhood Development, Health â€“ General, Immunization, Maternal And Newborn Health, Polio Eradication. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Improved and equitable use of high-impact maternal and child health intervention from pregnancy to adolescence and promotion of health behaviours

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Increased capacity to deliver high impact community based health interventions for women, newborns and under 5 children, includingpromotion of healthy behaviors, with special focus on gender equality and the most vulnerable, in all 13 districts by 2018

description.narrative: With increased training, supplies, and capacity, Community Health Workers (CHWs) conducted 58,453 high impact postnatal home visits, treated 211,113 children for malaria, 31,149 for pneumonia, 29,192 for diarrhea, screened 418,014 children for malnutrition, referred 45,465 acutely malnourished children to health facilities for treatment and 590 at-risk adolescent girls to health facilities and safe space. CHWs mobilized communities for the integrated measles and rubella (MR) catch-up campaign during which nearly 3 million children 9 months - <15 years (99 percent coverage) and over 1 million children 0-59 months received MR vaccines and oral Polio Vaccines, respectively. | Status:Met | As-of Date:05/02/2020
